Award.AwardTitle: Robust Identification and Model Validation for a Class of Nonlinear Dynamic Systems and Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Robust Identification and Model Validation for a Class of Nonlinear Dynamic Systems and Applications

The project seeks to develop a comprehensive framework for obtaining data driven models for a class of nonlinear systems that arise in the context of a broad range of applications that entail extracting information from high volume data streams. Obtaining these models is the first step towards developing a new class of systems with substantially enhanced capabilities to extract information sparsely encoded in multimodal, extremely large data sets. In particular, as a proof of concept, this project will focus on sustainable water quality management in urban environments, a problem that affects over one billion people in the Developing World and leads to losses estimated at over $2 billion/year in the US alone. From an education standpoint, this theme will be used to link a full range of distinct undergraduate and graduate courses, from systems theory, environmental and hydrologic engineering to machine learning, with emphasis on robustness and computational complexity. Undergraduate students will be engaged in research through the OUR Charles (Opportunities for Undergraduate Research on the Charles River) program.


While control of switched systems has made considerably progress in the past few years, the problem of identifying and validating hybrid models amenable to be used by these methods is far from solved. The present proposal aims at closing this gap by developing a computationally tractable framework for robust identification and model (in)validation of switched Hammerstein/Wiener systems. Its conceptual backbone is a combination of systems theory, semi-algebraic geometry and convex optimization elements that emphasizes robustness and computational complexity issues. The main idea is to recast the identification and model (in)validation of switched systems into a sparse semi-algebraic optimization form and to exploit recent advances in convex optimization to develop scalable, computationally tractable methods to solve these problems.

The advantages of the proposed approach include the ability to: (a) Address problems beyond the capabilities of existing techniques due to a combination of a lack of a comprehensive theoretical framework and poor scaling properties.
(b) Directly accommodate and respect features that are key to success in the relevant application domains, such as sparse interconnection structures. (c) Exploit a hitherto largely unexplored connection between systems identification and the problem of extracting actionable information from very large data sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to develop a comprehensive framework for obtaining data driven models and associated provably correct decisions,  for a class of nonlinear systems that arise in the context of a broad range of applications that entail extracting information from high volume data streams.  Obtaining these models is the first step towards developing a new class of systems with substantially enhanced capabilities to extract and act upon  information sparsely encoded in multimodal, extremely large data sets.  These systems, ranging from zero-emissions buildings to smart grids and smart cities can profoundly  impact society, enabling long term sustainable use of scarce resources. A major road-block to realizing this vision stemmed from the curse of dimensionality:  To successfully operate in these scenarios, controllers need to timely extract  actionable information from  very large data streams. However,  state-of-the-art techniques available at the time this project was started were ill-equipped to deal with this `"data avalanche".   One of the main motivations that drove this research was the observation that the problem of sparse dynamic information extraction from noisy,  fragmented data streams, could be recast into an identification/model (in)validation of switched systems. Briefly, in this approach, the observed data is treated as the output of an underlying dynamical system, with jumps indicating the occurrence of events, each characterized by a few parameters of the corresponding model. Thus, the approach developed here can be thought of as a generalization of the compressive sensing framework to a dynamical systems setting that exploits the structural properties of the underlying dynamics to locate, extract and act upon actionable information.

Project outcomes include:
(1) A computationally efficient framework for identification of switched systems. This method is substantially faster, and at the same time more robust to noise than the existing state of the art.
(2) An algorithm for unsupervised classification of data generated by switched linear systems. The computational complexity of this algorithm is practically independent of the number of data points and thus it is specially suited for big-data type applications. In addition we have developed alternative clustering algorithms that outperform the state of the art both in classification performance and execution time.
(3) A computationally tractable framework for synthesizing stabilizing controllers subject to information flow and topology constraints, based on the use of polyhedral Lyapunov functions combined with semi- algebraic optimization. 
(4) An agent-based model (ABM) of cyanobacteria. This model was applied  to a number of systems that experience cyanobacteria blooms, including the Great Lakes, Klamath River, Yahara River and Chattahoochee River, and used to explore the role of neutral evolution in the biogeography of these systems. Remarkably, the model showed  that dispersal limitation can be an important factor in microbe biogeography, which is contrary to the common belief, and could affect how a system responds to environmental change. 
(5) Application of the identification framework to several practical problems arising in the context of video-analytics, including motion segmentation, human activity analysis and fine grain classification.

Human resources: A total of eight graduate students in Electrical and Computer Engineering and  one in Civil Engineering were supported in this project, including 3 completed Ph.D dissertations. Four of the supported students are female and one belongs to a group traditionally underrepresented in engineering.

Results from this project were incorporated into graduate and senior level undergraduate courses taught at Northeastern University by the co-PIs. 

Dissemination:  These results were disseminated through presentations and papers published in major conferences and journals in the control and computer vision fields including the IEEE Trans. Automatic Control, Automatica, IEEE Conf. on Decision and Control, American Control Conf., Int. Conf. Computer Vision and the IEEE Conf. on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition.

In addition, M. Sznaier delivered plenaries and keynote talks at  the 2018 Rocond, 2018 SimTech, 2017 Benelux Meeting on Systems and Control, 2016 workshop on Geometric and Numeric Foundations of Movement, 2016 workshop on Taming Non-Convexity,  and the 2015 Symposium on Data Science and Systems Complexity.   Octavia Camps gave a keynote talk on "Dynamics-based Computer Vision" at the Women in Computer Vision Workshop at CVPR 2018, Salt Lake City, Utah in June 22, 2018.  This workshop was intended to increase the participation of women in STEM fields.

Technology Transfer: An application of the theoretical framework to the problem of anomaly detection (specifically, breaching of a sterile area) was sucessfully tested at an US airport in conjuction with TSA. Preliminary results indicate that the system achieves 0% misdetections and very few false alarms. We are currently exploring the feasibility of deploying this technology at other public transportation hubs such as rail stations. If these results are validated by extensive testing, these systems can substantially enhance security and reducing losses associated with security breaches that require closing down and evacuating public transportation hubs.
